title: Variables in JavaScript

explanation.short: JavaScript has three main ways to declare variables: var, let, and const.
explanation.detailed: Modern JavaScript uses let and const for most variables. let is used for values that can change, const for values that should not be reassigned. var is the older keyword and has function scope and hoisting behavior that often leads to bugs, so it is generally avoided in modern code.

key_points.description: Declared but not assigned a value.

best_practices: Prefer const by default and use let only when reassignment is needed.
Avoid var to prevent scoping and hoisting issues.
Use descriptive variable names instead of single letters.
Keep variables scoped as narrowly as possible.
Initialize variables when declaring them when practical.

common_mistakes.explanation: var is function-scoped, not block-scoped. Use let or const for block scope.
Variables declared with const cannot be reassigned.
Uninitialized variables are undefined and can cause unintended results.
